title: Dutch tech leaders: Europe won‚Äôt lead in AI hardware, but can in AI apps
description: The race to dominate AI infrastructure has left Europe trailing the US ‚Äî but the continent still has a shot at global leadership in AI apps. That was the verdict of Dutch tech leaders at the Assembly, the invite-only policy track of TNW Conference¬†in Amsterdam. While Silicon Valley controls the scaffolding for AI, they urged Europe to focus on building apps on top. Leading the call was Jeroen van Glabbeek, CEO and founder of CM.com, a customer engagement platform with a market cap of around ‚Ç¨217mn and annual revenues of ‚Ç¨274mn in 2024. Van Glabbeek believes the US advantage in‚Ä¶This story continues at The Next Web
author: Thomas Macaulay
excerpt: Europe has lost the AI hardware race to the US, but can still win on AI applications, Dutch tech leaders said at TNW Conference.
text: The race to dominate AI infrastructure has left Europe trailing the US ‚Äî but the continent still has a shot at global leadership in AI apps. That was the verdict of Dutch tech leaders at the Assembly, the invite-only policy track of TNW Conference¬†in Amsterdam. While Silicon Valley controls the scaffolding for AI, they urged Europe to focus on building apps on top. Leading the call was Jeroen van Glabbeek, CEO and founder of CM.com, a customer engagement platform with a market cap of around ‚Ç¨217mn and annual revenues of ‚Ç¨274mn in 2024. The üíú of EU techThe latest rumblings from the EU tech scene, a story from our wise ol' founder Boris, and some questionable AI art. It's free, every week, in your inbox. Sign up now!Van Glabbeek believes the US advantage in AI infrastructure could become a launchpad for European software. ‚ÄúThe infrastructure is already there,‚Äù he said. That infrastructure is being built with unprecedented investment. In 2025 alone, Meta, Amazon, Alphabet, and Microsoft plan to spend over $300bn (‚Ç¨261bn) combined on data centres, networking, and cloud services for AI, according to CNBC. Van Glabbeek called it ‚Äúthe biggest investment in technology in the history of mankind.‚Äù European tech firms can‚Äôt match this scale of spending on hardware. But they can capitalise by building AI apps on the foundations laid in the US. Europe already has a strong record of building top-tier apps, from Spotify and Grammarly to Revolut and Klarna. In the AI era, Van Glabbeek envisions a new wave of them emerging from the region. ‚ÄúWe won‚Äôt win the hyperscaler AI platform play, but there‚Äôs still something positive to compete for ‚Äî and it‚Äôs on the application side,‚Äù he said. The sentiment was echoed by other tech leaders on stage. Sohrab Hosseini, co-founder of Amsterdam-based generative AI startup Orq.ai, highlighted the opportunities at the ‚Äúorchestration and application levels,‚Äù while Lucien Burm, President of the Dutch Startup Association, pointed to where the profit lies. ‚ÄúThe money is probably to be made in the application layer,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to win that much in very deep AI hardware tech.‚Äù To fulfil Europe‚Äôs AI potential, the speakers called for a trio of financial changes: greater risk appetite from investors, less red tape around public funding, and more local procurement. But their most pressing demand is one that reverberates across the continent‚Äôs tech sector: innovation-friendly regulation.
html:
The race to dominate AI infrastructure has left Europe trailing the US ‚Äî but the continent still has a shot at global leadership in AI apps.

That was the verdict of Dutch tech leaders at the Assembly, the invite-only policy track of TNW Conference¬†in Amsterdam.

While Silicon Valley controls the scaffolding for AI, they urged Europe to focus on building apps on top.

Leading the call was Jeroen van Glabbeek, CEO and founder of CM.com, a customer engagement platform with a market cap of around ‚Ç¨217mn and annual revenues of ‚Ç¨274mn in 2024.

The üíú of EU tech

The latest rumblings from the EU tech scene, a story from our wise ol' founder Boris, and some questionable AI art. It's free, every week, in your inbox. Sign up now!

Van Glabbeek believes the US advantage in AI infrastructure could become a launchpad for European software. ‚ÄúThe infrastructure is already there,‚Äù he said.

That infrastructure is being built with unprecedented investment. In 2025 alone, Meta, Amazon, Alphabet, and Microsoft plan to spend over $300bn (‚Ç¨261bn) combined on data centres, networking, and cloud services for AI, according to CNBC.

Van Glabbeek called it ‚Äúthe biggest investment in technology in the history of mankind.‚Äù

European tech firms can‚Äôt match this scale of spending on hardware. But they can capitalise by building AI apps on the foundations laid in the US.

Europe already has a strong record of building top-tier apps, from Spotify and Grammarly to Revolut and Klarna. In the AI era, Van Glabbeek envisions a new wave of them emerging from the region.

‚ÄúWe won‚Äôt win the hyperscaler AI platform play, but there‚Äôs still something positive to compete for ‚Äî and it‚Äôs on the application side,‚Äù he said.

The sentiment was echoed by other tech leaders on stage.

Sohrab Hosseini, co-founder of Amsterdam-based generative AI startup Orq.ai, highlighted the opportunities at the ‚Äúorchestration and application levels,‚Äù while Lucien Burm, President of the Dutch Startup Association, pointed to where the profit lies.

‚ÄúThe money is probably to be made in the application layer,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to win that much in very deep AI hardware tech.‚Äù

To fulfil Europe‚Äôs AI potential, the speakers called for a trio of financial changes: greater risk appetite from investors, less red tape around public funding, and more local procurement. But their most pressing demand is one that reverberates across the continent‚Äôs tech sector: innovation-friendly regulation.
